4.13.20  2:01 am   Bill, I have an issue. I like to make projects, cool little events, sometimes a little funny video, perhaps a map to a video game and so on. But for years I've been struggling with three big problems.

First, when thinking about starting a project, I tend to struggle getting it started. In my mind I have this feeling that I know exactly what to do, but starting it just feels exhausting and I don't get things done. How do I kickstart myself to start those projects?

     it sounds like you still don't know specifically enough, the first steps. what helps me is to put on my own tv show, even if it's not actually on tv. you are the host of the show, and on the show, you will discuss and figure out how the hell to do the thing you are trying to do. and it will be fun and exciting as the audience follows along with your quest

     Second, when I get things started, I have this bad trait where I work on projects marathon style. For example, I do something for multiple days nonstop, but if I take even a smallest pause (like one day), the project just freezes instantly. How do I get rid of this marathon mentality?

     very specific bookmarks will help. write down exactly where you left off. very very specifically exactly what the next exact thing is.

     Third, even if things are rolling, sometimes I start to think elsewhere. "Damn, that's a great idea!" New projects that I should absolutely do! But there's this other project I' m alread y working on and that would just give me extra work. How does one simply focus on one project at a time while maintaining other amazing, potential ideas?

     keep an idea bank. add ideas to it. watch the bank grow out of control

     start by writing things down

4.12.20  10:58 pm   I was trying to write a song and I noticed that if I stop after three chords and try and repeat, it doesn't sound complete. It only sounds complete if I repeat one of the three chords or add a new chord. Do you know why this is? For example, if I play C for four beats, then F for four beats, and then G for four beats, it doesn't sound complete until I play G for four more beats. Is there a way to write a song with three chords where each chord is only played for four beats and then the chord regression repeats?

     the default 'normal' sound, for time, tends to run in powers of 2. so lengths of 2, 4, 8, 16, are all normal sounding lengths. But that is without considering anything else. melody. lyric. context. if you put an interesting spin on things, using those devices (melody/lyric), you can get away with almost anything

4.12.20  6:27 pm   hey bill, i'm suddenly in charge of editing a song together and i don't really know what i'm doing. do you have any advice on what to do with the equalizer effect? that's the thing that i'm having the most trouble figuring out on my own so far.

     here's the thing: don't use it if you don't need it. but if you are curious about what it does, go ahead and turn all the low frequencies down, and leave the high ones up. then listen. then put it back, and then turn the high frequencies down, and keep the low ones up. now listen. i think you will now understand exactly what it does. (you may recall this from knobs on a music player for 'treble' and 'bass', but this is the more detailed version of that.) So now, if you listen to something, and you notice it has too much low, or too much high, or not enough low or not enough high, etc etc, now you might now what to do. but please don't use it if the sound already sounded fine. that's the golden rule
